abstracts.cdata!:
The outcome of the Power Rehabilitation
            Project for Sierra Leone was unsatisfactory, the
            sustainability was unlikely, the institutional development
            impact was modest, and the Bank and borrower performance
            were both unsatisfactory. The lessons learned indicate that
            the approach to power system development in Sierra Leone has
            been fragmented rather than integrated. It might have been
            helpful for the Staff Appraisal Report to focus on issues
            such as cost reduction, which would involve rehabilitating
            oil-based generation and also actively seeking alternatives,
            such as hydropower, as well as low-cost distribution
            facilities. In post-conflict situations with significant
            destruction of infrastructure, the physical aspects of power
            development may take precedence over the institutional
            development aspects of power system development; and it may
            not be possible to move rapidly to the full privatization of
            a power utility. Local efficient utility management
            contractors are likely to have an advantage over foreign
            managers. They can be more adept in preparing and selling
            reform packages to the public and are likely to inspire a
            greater sense of trust. Although a project's objectives
            may be general enough to encompass a restructuring, major
            reallocations of resources may change indicators used to
            evaluate the achievement of objectives. For example,
            devastation during the conflict led to the restructuring of
            the Sierra Leone Rehabilitation Project, putting more focus
            on rehabilitation of physical infrastructure and less
            emphasis on institutional development of National Power
            Authority and future power system development. The lack of
            attention to modifying the objective can cause difficulties
            in the evaluation of project performance at completion.

repnme.cdata!: Sierra Leone - Power Sector Rehabilitation Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The objectives of the project are to :
            a) assist the National Power Authority (NPA) carry out long
            delayed maintenance and rehabilitation of its Western Area
            generation, subtransmission, and distribution facilities;
            and b) strengthen NPA as an institution in order to lay the
            foundations for an autonomous and commercially viable
            entity.  The project includes three main components : 1)
            maintenance and rehabilitation of generation facilities, and
            replacement of three decommissioned generators with two new
            ones; 2) rehabilitation and improvements in the
            subtransmission and distribution network; and 3)
            institutional strengthening of NPA through revision of the
            NPA Act, contracting a private firm to manage NPA, and
            training for NPA staff.
